This series is my way of giving back to the SAP community — consolidating practical tips, configurations, and hands-on insights to help anyone explore and implement BTP, SuccessFactors, and security solutions confidently.

Quick Tip !

I have used an SAP BTP Trial account to create the scenarios for all these blogs, so everyone will be able to perform hands-on exercises by following the steps shared in the blogs by just requesting SAP BTP Free trial account.

entry.title: Re: SAP Community 2024 QA formatting "Increase Indent" do...
entry.content:
Maybe I have added confusion by talking about the HTML tags: my question is about the standard button "Increase Indent".

ADDENDUM: if I may investigate the issue, we can see that the HTML code is:

The relevant CSS selectors for <p class="lia-indent-padding-left-60px"> are:

  1. For any element with the class "lia-indent-padding-left-60px":
  2. For any element inside <div id="bodyDisplay" class="lia-message-body"><div class="lia-message-body-content">

The corresponding selector specificities (Assigning property values, Cascading, and Inheritance) are:

  1. 0,0,1,0
  2. 0,1,2,2

Hence the padding of the second selector is retained and padding left is ignored.

entry.title: Re: Why Does BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2 Show Wrong Co...
entry.content:
In pricing, KBETR is not stored as the “human‑readable” amount; it is stored in internal units based on the condition’s pricing unit (KPEIN) and condition unit (KMEIN). For example, if your condition type ZGTC is defined in customizing with Calculation type = per 100 units (or per %), Pricing unit = 10 or 100, then the internal value in KBETR is scaled accordingly. The display in VA02 multiplies the stored value by the pricing unit to show the “per unit” rate. So if you pass 94 with a pricing unit of 10, the display will show 940.00. This is a classic unit/scale mismatch when calling the BAPI.  The BAPI doesn’t “fix” it, it just stores what you give it, and the UI applies the scale.

The SAP note referred here explains the Condition value is multiplied by factor 10”) addresses a known scaling issue in older releases where the BAPI multiplied the passed condition value incorrectly because of missing or wrong pricing unit handling. If your system release is one of those covered by the note, and the symptom matches the note’s description (value multiplied by 10 unexpectedly), then applying it can help.

However, in most modern releases, the behaviour you’re seeing is by design.  You need to pass KBETR in the internal format: KBETR = <desired display value> / <pricing unit> and set KPEIN (pricing unit) and KMEIN (condition unit) correctly in the BAPI tables ORDER_CONDITIONS_IN and ORDER_CONDITIONS_INX.

So with the above findings, what you can do is check condition type ZGTC in V/06:

  • What is the calculation type?
  • What is the default pricing unit?

Pass matching KPEIN/KMEIN in the BAPI along with KBETR.  If you want 94.00 to display in VA02, and the pricing unit is 10, you must pass KBETR = 9.4 with KPEIN = 10. Only if you confirm you’re on a release where Note 886532 applies and the scaling is wrong despite correct KPEIN/KMEIN, should you apply the note.

entry.title: Re: Problem with activation of Business function (BS sets...
entry.content:
Please note when you activate a business function in SFW5, the system switches the switch framework status. Tries to activate the associated BC Sets into your customizing tables. If the BC Set content does not match the current table structure or existing entries, the activation terminates with “Postprocessing necessary when upgrade/update completed”.

In your case, the “Error when comparing BC Set … with customizing tables” means the BC Set content delivered for EA‑HR in 2023 FPS03 is not matching the current table definitions or entries in your fresh system. This can happen if the BC Set contains entries for tables that have been changed or are not yet generated in your client. There is a mismatch between the EA‑HR delivery package and the Support Package stack you’re on. The BC Sets require post‑upgrade activation steps (IMG activities) before they can be applied.

Please proceed with the below steps

Check SFW_BROWSER for EA‑HR dependencies. Some EA‑HR switches require other switches (e.g. HR‑related industry solutions) to be active first.

Run transaction SFW5 in “Simulation” mode to see the list of BC Sets and objects it will touch; note any that are red‑flagged.

In SCPR20, try activating EA‑HR‑AKH, EA‑HR‑IMG, EA‑HR‑MENU one by one. If they error, the long text will tell you which table/field is mismatched.

Sometimes SAP delivers correction BC Sets or adjusts the activation sequence in a note. Search for notes with component BC-SRV-SFW and PA-* for your release.

If the BC Sets fail because tables are missing, generate the missing tables by running the relevant HR IMG activities (e.g. Personnel Administration basic settings) before re‑running SFW5.

If this is a demo or sandbox and you just need EA‑HR active, you can force the switch active in SFW_BROWSER and then manually run the HR IMG to configure; but in a productive system you should resolve the BC Set mismatches properly.

With all the above steps performed and still if you feel, you are on a fully‑patched FPS03 system and all prerequisites are met, then raise an incident to SAP under component BC‑SRV‑SFW

entry.title: Re: What is the best approach in SAP ECC to transfer asse...
entry.content: Configure Cross-System Depreciation Areas to map only the common areas (01, 10, 20, 30) and deliberately exclude the sender-only areas (70, 71). Then, execute the transfer using transaction ABT1N.

entry.title: Re: How to check which Auth Checks a program in SAP does
entry.content:
Hello @radinator!

To extend role by Fiori app could be a bit challenging, but described time waste dancings in a loop have never been needed.

There are more ways howto.

As oldschool SAP Authorizations, I prefer to have prepared special test user with unlimited rights in QAS, start authtrace in background and then ask business to log into SAP using this special user and with the Fiori app do what required. Once done, I check authtrace, identify related  values and fill them into SU24. On S/4 is possible create variants for every t-code, so I do, then merge role with new values and generate profiles. If the"test task" was done right way, after that all needed rights should be in role.

Using these steps for each new rights requested in last years. Seems complicated but proven as helpful, the bonus given is the consistency kept quite easier 🙂

BR, Olga

entry.title: Part 2: Agentic AI – Governance, risks and dilemmas
entry.content:
Agentic AI is jet another evolution of Traditional AI, right? It brings more than Generative AI (GenAI), but is also carries out some more risks as well… It’s becoming “smart”, it’s making “decisions” – and IBM told us in 1979 we shouldn’t let computers make “decisions” because computers cannot be “accountable”[1]!

I’ve tried to explain the AI evolution path in my previous article (Agentic AI – AI which finally makes sense?). Now, let’s talk about governance, risks and ethical dilemmas.

We should be aware of it, and we should try to address it – in time…

Let’s start with dilemmas…

Agentic AI can make autonomous decisions and based on this it can execute some complex tasks – also autonomously. This can be useful, yes – for sure this is much more than just GenAI assistants, where we had to make the decision and execute task on our own. Now we can have real robotic personal assistants, or self-driving cars, or robotic support agents. Tomorrow (and this tomorrow can come very fast) we will have fully autonomous HR agents and procurement officers, as well as fully autonomous industrial and humanoid robots, and let’s say this loudly – war robots as well (oh, I am sure bunch of people are already working on it, as we speak).

Figure 1. Are we concerned?

Dilemma is clear – where does this lead us at the end? Are we, out of our curiosity (or need to simplify our lives?) producing something which can replace us, or worse?

I do not have an answer on this – future is unwritten chapter – we are writing it now.

Agentic AI is reality, and now we should find the best way to use it! But at the same time,  we must create our future in a smart and sustainable way – and I hope we will.

Now, risks…

As per risks with Agentic AI, like with any AI or GenAI, there are some “standard” risks, for sure. But here I see that primary risk, is the risk of misuse by design – and this I link with the above dilemmas… I am not referring only to wrong design (i.e. being bias), I am referring on more serious “intentional” use for the “wrong” cause. What kind of agents and robots do we want to build? How much autonomy do we really want to give to AI? Although there are many articles, there are effectively no binding principles and guidelines. We are still too much intrigued with Agentic AI (or AI in general) – so no boundaries are set.

But it should be! As long as we do not set reasonable (and sustainable) boundaries, we are at (major?) risk.

Figure 2. Key Risks leading to shortcomings

For the “standard” risks, we have all those any GenAI might have – starting with security vulnerabilities like prompt injection and data poisoning, to model hallucinations. With Agentic AI both can lead not just to “ill” recommendations, but to “bad” decisions and “wrong” actions taken.

Additional risk, also starting with GenAI – the more cognitive tasks we pass to AI, the less cognitive tasks we will execute – this may not be good, in the long run. Similar with Agentic AI – the more decisions and actions are done by AI, the more dependent we become – again, this is not good for us, in the long run.

Are we aware of these risks? Well, we should be…

Can we improve “things” with good Governance?

The key aspect of any governance is to, among others, minimize any shortcomings of the new tools, methods, projects etc. How can we do this for Agentic AI?

  • How do we ensure that Agentic AI System has been built in the transparent and explainable way – so we can easily understand its purpose and ability?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI is fair and responsible – that we do see it as non-bias in making decision?
  • How do we build-in accountability within Agentic AI System (even these are “computers”) – in a way humans can accept it (also avoiding misuse by design)?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI System is safe to operate of – prompt injection and data poisoning has been effectively prevented.

Many questions… But what are the key governing principles we must follow?

First and the most important – there are no strict or imposed principles and guidelines (at least not yet) what is that Agentic AI System (agent or robot) can and cannot do by design. So, if we talk about “formal” misuse of the technology – sorry there are none or close to none (at least formally) limitations. But “informally” yes – there are those “dilemmas” for potential misuse of the AI (by design).

While it looked like we were very far away from the “real” AI (it was just a hype, right?) we did not care too much about putting any “legislation”. However, now things do not look so distant... The closer we come to real technology break-through toward autonomous robotics – thighs are becoming more and more controversial.

So how to build AI, and especially Agentic AI (or some further evolutions) in a responsible manner?

Figure 3. Responsible AI is Human-centric

Let’s call this Responsible AI magic circle of “interaction”:

  • Agentic AI “imposes” certain Risks
  • Risks do “impact” us, Human
  • Human must “build” Governance rules and practices
  • Governance rules and practices are here to “control” Agentic AI

The fact currently there are no “legally” binding rules and principles, does not prevent us to set company or industry standards on our own – let’s call it AI best practice.

If we talk about rules, let’s start thinking – what is that we want to keep for ourselves? What is that we don’t want AI to do? How far are we from some futuristic scenarios and the need to build basic rules of robotics[2]? Maybe we should be ready to “move over” this mountain and embrace the fact “future is happening right now”!

For principles, things are a bit more straight-forward, and previous AI experiences can really help us:

  1. Risk management: identifying, assessing, and mitigating the unique risks posed by both GenAI and autonomous agents. We should try to address all risks; from compliance risks and what and why do we build (to be transparent and explainable, to be fair and responsible, and ensure maximum possible accountability), to security risks (to be safe to operate).
  2. Continuous monitoring and auditing: agents/robots need to be monitored continuously to detect any deviation from intended behavior, any ethical issues, or security breaches. Also, audit trails and logging of agent decisions are vital for accountability, where (ideally) no agents/robots should access, alter and remove any audit trails and logs.
  3. Organizational structure: creating a cross-functional AI governance boards and bodies to create policies but also monitor adaptation of these policies in all Ai initiatives, with special focus on agents/robots.

All this, and more if needed, can be easily translated into any organization dealing with Agentic AI. Each organization will make adaptations on its own, of course – but key is to be aware of risks and shortcomings, as well as all the potential benefits new Agentic AI technology is bringing. If we are aware, and we try addressing it with proper governance – it’s a good start…

So, can we start all this and be open-minded?

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo BoliviaInteligente on Unsplash

**) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use  governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] IBM: AI decision-making: Where do businesses draw the line? | IBM

[2] Isac Asimov: Three Laws of Robotics - Wikipedia

entry.title: Skills in SAP SuccessFactors: Field Guide for a Clean Build (TIH, JPB, CPM, OMP)
entry.content:
Skills in SuccessFactors only clicks when you separate people from jobs: Growth Portfolio (TIH) for people, Job Profile Builder for roles. This guide shows exactly what to enable, how to govern signals and write-back, and how to prove value in 90 days.

Applies to: SAP SuccessFactors Platform: Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) / Growth Portfolio, Job Profile Builder (JPB), Performance & Goals (incl. CPM), Opportunity Marketplace, People Intelligence.

Why read this: If you’re setting up or rescuing a skills program in SuccessFactors, this is the no-nonsense blueprint: what owns what, what to enable, what to measure, and what to avoid.

 

One idea to anchor everything

People ≠ Jobs. 

In SuccessFactors, people skills live in the Growth Portfolio (TIH Job Role details live in Job Profile Builder. Don’t try to force one to replace the other. Map roles and required attributes in JPB; curate and evidence people’s skills in TIH. Most downstream confusion disappears when you keep those two sources of truth separate.

Architecture at a glance

  • Talent Intelligence Hub (Growth Portfolio): the person-centric skills profile (attributes, proficiency, evidence, history).
  • Job Profile Builder: job-centric content (families, roles, competencies/skills). Consumed by Recruiting, Performance, etc.
  • Signals & Inference: Continuous Performance Management (CPM) can feed TIH to recommend skills; you promote to confirmed with governance.
  • Opportunity Marketplace (OMP): skills drive opportunity matching; completions can surface as growth evidence.
  • People Intelligence: the analytics destination for skills coverage, gaps, mobility, think “post-WFA.”

Enablement: the minimal viable path

1) Turn on Growth Portfolio (TIH)
Admin Center → Company Settings → Manage Talent Intelligence Hub → Portfolio Settings → Enable

2) Seed the Attributes Library
Admin Center → Growth Portfolio → Add from Attributes Library → Set proficiency scales
Recommendation: Start with 3 pilot families; cap role profiles at 15–25 skills to keep matching sane.

3) Keep JPB as the job backbone
Use families/roles and attach the right attributes.

Recommendation: Don’t flood; use Core vs. Nice-to-have.

4) Wire CPM → TIH inference (optional but powerful)

  • Enable “Allow CPM data to support skills inferencing in TIH” via AI Services Administration.
  • In Scheduled Jobs, verify three CPM → TIH jobs (Achievements / Activities / Feedback) show COMPLETED SUCCESSFULLY; otherwise your “AI” sees nothing.

5) Opportunity Marketplace hygiene
Ensure opportunities are tagged to skills; confirm that opportunities and completions surface in Growth experiences (incl. non-intelligent recs in skill detail).

Governance that actually reduces noise

  • Naming rules: one canonical label per skill; merge duplicates monthly.
  • Role caps: keep roles lean (≤40 skills).
  • Evidence rules: define what counts (learning completion, gig completion, manager validation).
  • Skill owners: assign by family; review quarterly.
  • Change control: Promote INFERRED → CONFIRMED via admin workflow, not ad hoc.
    These basics improve match quality more than any “magic” toggle. (Principles derived from SAP docs + partner implementation notes.)

Privacy and compliance notes (don’t skip)

If you infer skills in the EU, treat them as personal data. Use DPCS 2.0 where applicable; ensure lawful basis, notices, and opt-outs are documented. Works-council agreements don’t replace GDPR obligations, get both right.

Fast checks:

  • DPCS 2.0 enabled in Provisioning and statements created per country.
  • Audit acceptance in Admin Center → Data Privacy Statement → View History / View Log.

Reporting: stop thinking like old WFA

Plan your shift to People Intelligence to mix skills + mobility + business metrics. That’s the arena where execs see impact (time-to-fill, internal moves, project margin), not just skill counts.

Also: use the out-of-the-box TIH Stories.
Report Center → Story → Content Store has ready-made Story templates you can import and tweak. They run on People Analytics (Stories), so you can report directly on TIH/Growth Portfolio objects: Attributes, Attribute Types, Tags, Growth Portfolio, Behaviors, Proficiency Levels/Sets, without building a model from scratch. Start with these templates:

  • SF_TIH_Talent_Intelligence_Hub_HR_Admin_Dashboard
  • SF_TIH_Talent_Intelligence_Hub_Manager_Dashboard

 

then add pages for coverage, gap-to-role, mobility, and evidence quality. If you see duplicate rows in Growth Portfolio stories, that’s the history (effective-dated) view, switch to “latest record only” in your query

Cost control: budget the AI, not just the project

TIH (Growth Portfolio) is part of platform at no additional cost. But, the premium AI features consume SAP AI Units – all AI services listed below. Track and estimate usage early or your pilots stall later.

  • Where to track: Admin Center and SAP for Me consumption dashboards.
  • How it works (estimator & catalog): SAP’s AI Unit Estimator / Business AI catalog.

Open skills: don’t start from zero

If your library is thin, lean on partners that sync with TIH to solve cold-start: TechWolf, Degreed, and others announced by SAP. Use them to normalize and ingest signals rather than hand-curating everything.

A 90-day rollout that works

Days 1–15: Foundation

  • Enable TIH; clean JPB families/roles; seed a small, governed library.
  • Define evidence rules; assign skill owners.

Days 16–45: Signals & flow

  • Switch on CPM → TIH inference via AI Services; verify scheduled jobs.
  • Tag opportunities; validate that Growth experiences reflect completions/recs.

Days 46–90: Prove value

  • Publish People Intelligence dashboards (coverage, gap-to-role, internal mobility).
  • Run one mobility or gig pilot; track time-to-fill and redeploy rate.

 

FAQ

Q: Can Performance form ratings update Growth Portfolio automatically?
A: Performance consumes attributes for rating, but write-back to Growth Portfolio isn’t automatic; design the evidence path or integrate via APIs/imports if you need it.

Q: Do opportunities “write back” to people’s skills?
A: You can surface opportunity recommendations in Growth experiences and use completions as evidence, but verify enablement and tagging; don’t assume full automation.

Q: Is People Intelligence just a rebrand of WFA?
A: It’s a next-gen analytics approach announced in 2024/2025 communications (built on SAP’s data cloud direction). Plan migration; don’t keep building WFA-style reports.

Q: How do I control AI cost?
A: Monitor AI Units; use the estimator and catalog; review consumption regularly in Admin / SAP for Me.

References:

  • Talent Intelligence Hub / Growth Portfolio — overview & enable steps. (SAP Help Portal)
  • Job Profile Builder — concept & content types. (SAP Help Portal)
  • CPM → TIH skill inference — concept + job checks. (SAP Help Portal)
  • Opportunity Marketplace interactions — recommendations in Growth experiences. (SAP Help Portal)
  • AI Units — tracking & estimation. (SAP Help Portal)
  • Privacy — DPCS 2.0 and admin auditing. (SAP Support Portal)
  • Open skills partners — TechWolf, Degreed & Any 3rd party. (SAP News Center)

entry.title: Field Mapping Mechanism and Troubleshooting Guide for Error "No Sales Scheduling Agreement Found"
entry.content:
This blog describes the field mapping mechanism and troubleshooting guide (from SAP backend) for the error "No Sales Scheduling Agreement Found" in the delivery schedule EDI, with the communication scenario SAP_COM_0444 (Sales Scheduling Agreements With Buyers Integration).

"Image/data in this blog is from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental." 

Step 1: Find the related EDI Message ID via T-code /AIF/ERR:

Step 2: Get the payload via T-code SRT_MONI:

Step 3: Get the values of related fields from the payload.

Below is the mapping of fields among the EDI payload, the sales scheduling agreement, and the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app:

EDI Payload

Sales Scheduling Agreement"Assign Sold-to Parties" app

PurchasingSchedulingAgreementID

Customer Reference 

BuyerProductID

Customer Material in the item of Sales Scheduling Agreement 

<Party PartyType="SoldTo">

<BuyerPartyID> 10100003 </BuyerPartyID>

</Party>

Sold-to PartySold-to Party

<Party PartyType="Supplier">

<BuyerPartyID> 10100001 </BuyerPartyID> 

</Party>

           

Supplier

<Party PartyType="Plant">   

<BuyerPartyID> 1010 </BuyerPartyID>

</Party>

Ship-to Party: Partner DefinitionPartner Description

<BuyerPartyID> 0001 </BuyerPartyID>

</Party>

Note: "Supplier" is optional in payload and the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app. However, if it is in the payload, it should also exist in the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app.

Step 4: Open the "Display Sales Scheduling Agreements" app and input the related search criteria (according to the EDI Payload) to find the corresponding sales scheduling agreement:

 Step 5: If the values among the EDI payload, the sales scheduling agreement (SA), and the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app don't map, no sales scheduling agreement can be found.

entry.title: Reusable APIs in SAP Integration Suite : Design Once, Use Everywhere
entry.content:
Introduction

Reusable API  artifacts in SAP Integration Suite – Edge Integration Cell are modular, internal-only APIs that encapsulate common cross-cutting concerns such as authentication, transformation, validation, or logging.

Instead of duplicating the same policies across multiple APIs, Reusable API act as centrally managed building blocks that can be invoked by other API artifacts through  a special API Direct adapter.

 Key characteristics:

Internal only: They are not exposed as standalone endpoints.

Policy encapsulation: Common logic like authentication or schema validation is defined once and reused.

Independent lifecycle: They can evolve separately from consuming APIs, supporting cleaner governance and versioning.

Performance-aware: Optimized for low-latency chaining between calling APIs and Reusable API s, with correlation IDs ensuring full traceability.

Consistency & compliance: Authentication policy is enforced uniformly across the execution chain.

Use Cases it Addresses

Reusable API artifacts address several real-world challenges faced by API developers and central security/governance teams:

🔑Centralized Security Enforcement

Instead of configuring authentication and authorization separately in every API, organizations can define a Reusable API  artifact with standard security policies (e.g., OAuth/JWT verification, API key validation, IP allowlist). Any new API simply invokes this artifact, ensuring compliance with enterprise-wide standards and reducing the risk of inconsistent security coverage.

⚙️Policy Reuse & Reduced Duplication

Enterprises often repeat the same transformations (e.g., XML-to-JSON), validations (e.g., schema checks), or response formatting across multiple APIs. By centralizing these policies into Reusable API  artifacts, teams avoid duplication, simplify maintenance, and accelerate delivery of new APIs.

📊Auditability & Governance

With traceability built in via correlation IDs, Reusable API  artifacts give central teams visibility into how APIs interact across the execution chain. This is particularly useful in regulated industries where demonstrating uniform enforcement of policies (like logging or data masking) is mandatory.

🚀Accelerated API Development

Developers can focus on business-specific logic in their APIs while leveraging pre-built Reusable API  artifacts for cross-cutting concerns. This speeds up delivery, ensures consistency, and lowers onboarding time for new API projects.

 Creating and consuming a Reusable API Artifact

   Prerequisites
  • Enable API Management and Cloud Integration capabilities  and 
  • Provision Edge Integration Cell runtime.

After you have setup Edge Integration Cell and enabled both the capabilities mentioned above, you will have option to create API artifact. 

         In a typical organization, two key personas benefit the most from reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite:

  1. Central Security Administrator – responsible for defining and enforcing security standards across all exposed APIs. They ensure consistent authentication, authorization, and compliance policies without duplicating effort.
  2. API Developer – responsible for designing APIs in Integration Suite, modelling business logic, and creating proxies for backend services. With reusable APIs, they can focus on business functionality while relying on centrally managed security and governance.

Lets create a Reusable API as security administrator persona :

 A security administrator logs in to the Integration Suite tenant and navigates to Design → Integrations and APIs, then selects an existing content package to model a Reusable API.

              

Select the Edge Integration Cell runtime profile and proceed to choose the API creation method. Among the four available options, you will notice a new entry: Reusable API.

 

 

Provide the required API details to create a Reusable API .

 

Important to note: A Reusable API artifact does not require a target URL or a virtual host since it is designed for internal invocation only via a calling API  using the API Direct adapter. Therefore, it does not have an externally invokable endpoint.

Once all the details are provided, click on Create to create a Reusable API .

 

The sender adapter in a Reusable API is automatically set to API Direct. This is important because it allows the calling API artifact to invoke the Reusable API internally—without an HTTP endpoint and without external exposure. Now, let’s add a few security policies like Authentication and Authorization to it.

 

 

 

In addition to security policies, you can add mediation policies to extend functionality. For example:

  • Use a Content Modifier to enrich or adjust the message payload.
  • Configure an External Callout to log data to external services such as Loggly.

With these steps, we’ve modelled a Reusable API that handles authentication and authorization, while also logging transaction details to an external system.

Consuming the Reusable API

Let’s model a caller API that proxies an external backend while consuming the Reusable API created in the previous steps.

Provide the mandatory details for the caller API.

For a standard API, an Authentication policy is always applied as the first policy by default. However, when consuming a Reusable API that already includes an authentication policy, you should remove the default authentication policy from your calling API. This ensures there’s no duplication or conflict.

As a boundary condition: The first step in your calling API must be either Authentication policy or a Reusable API with Authentication policy as its first step. This keeps the flow clean, avoids redundant auth checks, and maintains proper execution order.

Now, let’s add a step to invoke the Reusable API created earlier. As the first step, add the reusable API artifact as a global reference in your caller API, as shown below. 

The Reference dialog will display only the deployed Reusable APIs within a package. If you need to reference multiple reusable APIs, you can add them from different content packages simultaneously.

To consume the reusable API, add a Request-Reply step along with a Receiver System to invoke the reusable API. From the list of adapters, select API Direct only. Since the reusable API already includes an Authentication policy, go ahead and delete the authentication policy from your calling API to avoid duplication.

 

Let’s click on API Direct to configure the adapter’s connection details, which enables us to reference the reusable API added earlier as a global reference in this API.

 

Now, let’s examine the properties associated with the API Direct adapter in detail.

 

 a) Resource :This allows you to associate any added reusable API as a reference to this API.  

 b) Address :A read-only field that displays the basepath of the reusable API added in the Resource section. 

 c) Send Body  :Check this box to send the original request body to the reusable API. This is typically used with   POST, PUT, or PATCH methods, where the request payload must be preserved and forwarded to the reusable     flow. 

 d) Retain Original Body for Next Steps : Select this option to keep the original request body available for use in subsequent steps of your caller API.

 e) Headers

  • Request Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers (e.g., Authorization|X-Correlation-ID) to send to the reusable API.
    Use * to send all headers by default.
  • Response Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers from the reusable API’s response that should be merged into the caller API’s original request headers.
    Use * to receive and merge all response headers by default.

Now we have modelled and consumed a Reusable API into the caller API. Please note that if the Reusable API is not deployed, then you will not be allowed to deploy the caller API referring that Reusable API . Now let’s deploy the caller API.

As both caller and Reusable APIs are deployed, Lets check the status and also invoke the caller.

Monitor and Message logs

Once APIs are deployed lets navigate to Monitor section to introspect the both Caller and the Reusable APIs under Manage Integration Content.

 

One important point to note about reusable APIs is that, since they don’t have an external endpoint, the Endpoints section does not display any entry as shown above.

 Let change the log level to Trace for both the artifacts.

Now let me invoke the caller API endpoint via a REST client.

 

Let’s now check the correlation ID for this transaction in both the caller and reusable API logs — they should ideally be the same, ensuring end-to-end traceability.

As you can see, the API was invoked successfully.

If you recall from earlier steps, we modelled the reusable API to provide Authentication & Authorization protection and included a mediation policy to log the correlation ID to the Loggly server.

As you can see, the same correlation ID is also being logged into the Loggly server.
Additionally, you can examine the trace details of the executed steps, which will show that the first step was executed via API Direct, exactly as we modelled in our use case.

 

Similarly, the same Reusable API is referred  to another API artifact by the API developer to leverage the centrally defined security and common tasks by administrator.

If a new traffic management policy like Surge protection policy is to be added to all the APIs then API administrator only needs to it to the Reusable API and it will be automatically applied to all the APIs referring the Reusable API.

Points to remember:

  1. At least one authentication policy is mandatory in complete chain including the caller API and Reusable API.
  2. Only Authentication policy or a request reply step to Reusable API can be added as first step in a valid caller API.
  3. A caller API can refer more than one Reusable API, but one Reusable API cannot refer another Reusable API.
  4. Only deployed reusable APIs can be added to the caller API.

Summary

Reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite bring clarity and efficiency to API management. By separating centralized enforcement from API development activities, organizations can achieve both governance and agility. The administrator gains confidence that policies are consistently applied, while the API developer can focus on delivering business value without reinventing the wheel for every project.

In short, reusable APIs strike the right balance between control and productivity, making them a cornerstone for scalable, enterprise-grade API strategies.

entry.title: Re: Streams in RAP : Uploading PDF , Excel and Other Files in RAP Application
entry.content:
Hi,
@RadhikaKuthiala 
@sandhyad 
@Mahiba 

When uploading a file via a child association(Line Items on Root Object Page) in an OData V4 service,
the error Entity set '' not found (/IWBEP/CM_V4_MED015) appears.

This only happens when accessing the attachment field through the parent entity (ROOT).
Uploading directly via the child service works fine,
and the file is then also visible through the parent as expected.

Solution:

I extended the object page of the ROOT entity,
and overrode the client-side upload function to redirect the file upload directly to the child entity's service.
This avoids the "Entity set not found" error and ensures successful uploads.

Code Snippet (Controller Extension):

sap.ui.define(['sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension',
    'sap/m/MessageToast'
], function (ControllerExtension, MessageToast) {
    'use strict';

    return ControllerExtension.extend('studentapp.ext.controller.StudentObjectPage', {
        override: {
            /**
             * Called when a controller is instantiated and its View controls (if available) are already created.
             * Can be used to modify the View before it is displayed, to bind event handlers and do other one-time initialization.
             * @memberOf studentapp.ext.controller.StudentObjectPage
             */
            onInit: function () {
                this.getInterface().fixBugEntitySetNotFound();
            },

        },

		/*
			changes upload url 
		    From : "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zhr_sb_student_v4/srvd/sap/zhr_sd_student/0001/ZHR_C_STUDENT_APP(parentKeys...)/_StudentAttachments(childKeys...)/Attachment"
			To:    "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zhr_sb_student_v4/srvd/sap/zhr_sd_student/0001/ZHR_C_STUDENT_ATTACHMENTS(childKeys...)/Attachment"
		*/
        fixBugEntitySetNotFound: function () {

            if (!sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype._bUploadOverwritten) {

                sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype._bUploadOverwritten = true;
                var fOrignalUpload = sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype.upload;
				
                sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype.upload = function (bPreProcessFiles) {

                    /* Extend - Begin */
                    var sParentService = "ZHR_C_STUDENT_APP", //root service
                        sChildService = "ZHR_C_STUDENT_ATTACHMENTS", //child service
                        sChildAssociation = "_StudentAttachments",
                        sUrl = this.getUploadUrl(),
                        sNewUrl = "";

                    if (sUrl.includes(sParentService) &&
                        sUrl.includes(sChildAssociation)) {

                        sNewUrl = sUrl.split(sParentService)[0] + sChildService + sUrl.split(sParentService)[1].split(sChildAssociation)[1]
                        this.setUploadUrl(sNewUrl)
                    }
                    /* Extend - End */

                    fOrignalUpload.apply(this, arguments);

                };
            }
        }
    });
});


Best Regards,
Ben.

entry.title: Re: Manual Cheque Number Assignment for Outgoing Payments
entry.content:
@silambarasan_RS 

Dedicated Manual Lot: Create a separate cheque lot (e.g., MANUAL_CHQ) with Number Assignment = External. Do not mix internal and external assignments in the same lot. This provides clarity and prevents errors.

Duplicate Prevention: The system will not stop you from entering a duplicate cheque number if you use external assignment. You must have a rock-solid internal process (e.g., a physical logbook or a control spreadsheet) to track which cheque numbers have been used to prevent duplicates.

Security and Controls: Access to transaction FCHI and FPM2 should be restricted to authorized finance personnel due to the risk of duplicate entries and the potential for fraud.

Testing: Always test this configuration thoroughly in your development (DEV) or quality (QAS) system before implementing it in production. Create a test cheque lot and process a few manual and automatic payments to ensure the behavior is as expected.

entry.title: Re: Automatic Posting to Account Foreign exchange gain re...
entry.content:
@Dasun_T 

You thought the forex loss would be 237,094.42 and recorded that expense.

When the transaction finished, the real loss was only 164,142.29.

SAP automatically reverses the extra expense you recorded by booking an income of 72,952.13. This corrects your books to reflect the true, final loss of 164,142.29.

The total P&L impact is now correct: 237,094.42 (Loss Expense) - 72,952.13 (Gain Income) = 164,142.29 (Net Loss), which matches the actual cash difference.

entry.title: SSO Migration to our Company New Domain
entry.content:
we are undergoing a branding change for our company. Hence our Domain ID is being changed.

entry.title: Re: Old Supplier invoice not created with reference to in...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Cloud, there is no standard EDI output automatically triggered for Accounts Payable invoices at the time of posting. However, I would like to kindly share an alternate solution supported in the system:

  • Payment Advice via Output Parameter Determination: You can configure automatic remittance/payment advice as an outbound document. In Output Parameter Determination, select Payment Advice and maintain rules for channel (example, Email) and recipient (supplier BP e-mail). During payment runs, the system automatically issues the remittance advice, which can be sent directly to the supplier or routed through middleware to be converted into an EDI message.
    This is the most commonly used and fully standard approach.

I hope this additional information helps you in your query. 

Thank you so much. 
Kind Regards,
Iza

entry.title: Issue with several fields referencing the same object in a HANA Star Join
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am struggling with making a HANA Calculation view in HANA Cloud (built using the HANA Artefact tools in Business Application Studio), where my information cube includes a reference to the same dimension in several columns. The simplified example is as follows:

A table of Business Partners consisting of ID and Name. For this I have made a Dimension view named "BusinessPartner" consisting of a "Business Partner ID" and "Business Partner Name" column.

A table of Sales Orders consisting of ID, SellerID and BuyerID, the latter both being references to a record in the Business Partner table. For this I have made a Cube view.

Lastly, I want to add the "BusinessPartner" dimension to the Start Schema at the top. Once as "Seller" and once as "Buyer". This is the seemingly trivial scenario I am not able to accomplish. I am running into the following challenges

  • I cannot bring the same Dimension view into the Cube more than once (which I can overcome by creating synonyms)
  • Regardless of me changing the Label Aliases, the dimension still comes out as "Business Partner" (I need it to be "Seller" and "Buyer").

The only way I have so far been able to get the desired end result (the "Seller" and "Buyer" dimensions showing to the end user in Analytics Cloud) is to create a Dimension View for each purpose the referenced object has (i.e. no generic "BusinessPartner" dimension but instead one "Seller" dimension and one "Buyer" dimension). While I am getting the right end result that way, it becomes a nightmare to build and maintain all those dimension views where the only difference is their labels.

I hope the issue is clearly described and that somebody can put me on the right track. Thanks!

//Carl

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP:Disaggregation at two levels
entry.content:

As IBP allows only one logic of disaggregation in one KF, you will have to create two different key figures:

1. Requirements -> Req. at Group Plan ( Disagg by Grade%)

2. Req. at Group Plan -> Req. at Next level (Disagg by Count%)

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Rahul Mohnot

entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - September 2025
entry.content:
Summary

This months report focuses on the strategic transformation of procurement and accounts payable (AP). Lots of research covering AI including deploying AI-powered orchestration, elevating procurement from tactical operations to strategic business partnership, with a focus on integrated data, governance, and human-in-the-loop decision-making. AI adoption accelerates spend analysis, supplier collaboration, automation, and compliance, but practical barriers persist—legacy systems, fragmented data, and organizational silos.

A review shows that next-generation procurement leaders prioritize resilience, sustainability, innovation, and supplier enablement, positioning modern AP and contract management as essential drivers of financial performance and business agility

Procurecon

Two procurement reports from Procurement, one sponsored by GEP about orchestration and the other by ProcureAbility about AI adoption. As they cover some of the same topics, ive combined the analysis.

GEP's report paints an expansive future where procurement evolves from functional process to strategic orchestrator. With 90% of leaders facing increasing complexity, the solution lies in comprehensive AI-powered orchestration spanning intake management, end-to-end source-to-pay, and cross-domain integration. The vision is compelling: agent-based architectures converting user intentions into automated subtasks, natural language interactions replacing complex interfaces, and procurement professionals freed from tactical work to focus on strategic value creation.

ProcureAbility's research grounds this vision in current reality. While 92% express satisfaction with AI solutions, the implementation story is more nuanced. Most organizations (59%) use AI tactically for specific initiatives rather than comprehensive integration, with 90% lacking confidence in measuring ROI. Despite strong investment intentions (88% increasing spending), challenges around proven examples and change resistance persist.

Both reports agree on fundamental shifts: procurement's democratization (40% of sourcing by non-procurement staff by 2027), the primacy of data analytics investments (70% prioritizing by 2030), and AI's role in supplier management and spend analysis. The success metrics align too – cost savings, sustainability improvements, and operational efficiency lead realized benefits.

However, the reports differ on readiness. GEP's orchestration vision assumes organizations can leap to comprehensive AI integration, while ProcureAbility's suggests most remain in moderate implementation phases. This gap between vision and reality reflects the classic technology adoption curve –success stories drive ambitious roadmaps, but broader adoption faces practical hurdles.

Beroe – AI report

According to the report, the strategic role of AI in  Procurement is now expected to deliver strategic value—cost savings, risk mitigation, supply resilience, ESG impact—not just transactional efficiency. However, legacy systems and fragmented data block progress. Success therefore depends on three pillars: Data Excellence (harmonised, contextual, trusted data), Intelligent Recommendations (contextual, prioritised insights versus static reports), and Simplicity and Relevance (role-specific, accessible information).

The report cautions that not all AI is equal. Tasks like invoice matching best suit rules-based AI, while forecasting and risk modelling need predictive or generative AI. Human judgment remains central; AI augments, not replaces, professional decision-making.

The report suggest to start with real, high-impact decision problems. Assess and close data gaps. Prioritise early wins with well-defined use cases and build from pilots to scale, always embedding AI into user workflows and maintaining human-in-the-loop governance.

Barriers and Enablers: Data readiness, explainable AI, change management, integration with existing tools, and a shift from deterministic to probabilistic thinking are all critical for success. Governance and transparency build user trust

F5 - State of AI Application Strategy Report 2025

While 96% of organizations are experimenting with AI, only 2% are “highly ready.” Most are “moderately ready,” with AI present in about one-third of applications, used in pockets not end-to-end. Readiness depends on generative/agentic AI deployment, application diversity, model diversity (mix of paid/open-source models), penetration % of apps using AI, and formal practices like data labelling. High readiness means broad, well-orchestrated integration.

Moderately Ready Organizations:

  • Generative AI and AI agents in production, but immature in governance/security and lacking orchestration.
  • Tactics: Using both paid and open-source models for flexibility; starting to deploy AI firewalls and advanced data protection; adopting AI in analytics, security, and customer experience.

Barriers to High Readiness: Siloed use cases, inconsistent policies, security concerns, especially around data use and third-party risks. Low-readiness orgs often lack skilled resources and strategy to move from pilots to scaled execution.

Comparison

As these two reports came out in the same month, there are some consistent themes:

Implications for Procurement Leaders

AI is a Strategic Partner, Not a Silver Bullet: Both reports stress that AI must be applied purposefully, integrated across processes, and always with data readiness and governance front of mind—especially given regulatory, risk, and supply chain complexity.

From Reporting to Decision Support: Move away from static dashboards to proactive, explainable recommendations and scenario simulation. AI should guide “what to do next” rather than just reporting “what happened”.

Collaborative Human-AI Models: Maintain a “human-in-the-loop” paradigm, where procurement professionals validate, explain, and direct AI recommendations. This both builds adoption and avoids “black-box” pitfalls

Comparison: Agreements and Contrasts

 

Beroe: Real Decisions

F5: AI Strategy 2025

AI’s Role

Augmenting, not replacing, human decisions; domain focus

Core infrastructure, not a feature; operational focus 

Readiness Definition

Data excellence, integrated recommendations, simplicity

Orchestrated, broad app/model integration, formal governance 

Tech Adoption Path

Real-world use cases → pilots → scale, always with HITL

Model diversity, security, broad use → mature into platform 

Key Barriers

Fragmented data, lack of explainability, trust

Siloed deployments, poor orchestration, insufficient governance 

Success Factors

Fit-for-purpose AI, role-tailored insights, continuous feedback

Hybrid AI models, formal data labelling, security/observability 

Governance Themes

Human-in-the-loop, explainability, transparency

Data governance, labelling, firewalls, compliance 

 

SSON State of Ap 2025

The report highlights AP’s shift from a cost centre to a strategic driver, underpinning cash flow, compliance, and supplier relationships.

Top Challenges: Manual data entry, invoice matching errors, compliance complexity, and increased fraud risk are leading concerns. Only 10% feel “very equipped” for e-invoicing compliance. This emphasises the complexities of e-invoicing mandates (CTC), global tax/regulation, and advanced fraud risks. The report also highlights the need for integrated, modular platforms and proactive partnership with IT and vendors.

Key metrics include touchless invoice processing rate, invoice processing time, invoices processed per FTE, cost per invoice, and late payment rate. These are strategic levers for AP excellence, focused on automation and cost control.

AP teams are adopting AI for touchless processing, fraud detection, and vendor inquiries, but most are in early phases—less than 5% have reached high (>70%) automation levels

Ardent Partners State of e-payables 2025

This report which is a staple of the research community, tracks AP’s evolution from paper-pushing to insight-driven operation over two decades. COVID-19 accelerated adoption of e-Payables but paper invoices persist (>40%) and shows that Best-in-Class AP departments achieve $2.65 per invoice cost and 2.9 days per invoice cycle (vs. $12.42 and 13.5 days “All Others”). Exception rates, touchless processing, and supplier enablement are critical differentiators.

The report states that the key priorities are the need to deploy comprehensive e-Payables solutions, improving analytics/reporting, and supplier enablement are top priorities. Supplier participation is identified as the “Achilles heel” for digital transformation. Best-in-Class AP teams have much higher adoption rates of automated routing/workflow (80%), e-Invoicing (79%), e-Payments (77%), and tend to use integrated payment networks.

AP’s strategic involvement in cash management, supplier management, and business intelligence is growing but uneven. Collaboration with procurement and treasury is essential for resilience (e.g., managing tariffs, payment timing, supply risk).

44% use AI today; 75% expected to within 12 months. Main objective is increased automation, but secondary priorities include forecasting, cost reduction, and stakeholder satisfaction.

Both the SSON and Ardent Partners 2025 reports position accounts payable (AP) as a critical, evolving function—moving from manual, transactional activity to an intelligent, value-generating hub within enterprises.

Comparison & Contrast.

Both reports stress the importance of tight alignment between procurement and AP for supplier enablement, payment optimization, and strategic sourcing. Procurement must partner with AP to drive spend visibility, compliance, and process innovation

Both agree that AP must transform into a strategic partner for procurement, finance, and the broader enterprise, and that success hinges on automation, intelligent analytics, supplier enablement, and compliance.

Both stress that AI adoption and modern e-Payables technologies will accelerate AP’s strategic contribution in the next 2–3 years, but acknowledge both barriers and opportunities remain

Area

SSON: State of Accounts Payable 2025

Ardent Partners: State of e-Payables 2025

Commonality

Difference

Strategic AP Role

Value centre, unified payment, embedded AI, continuous improvement

Insight hub, process control, spend/cash management, AI as enabler

Elevating AP to strategic, proactive function

SSON stresses compliance/fraud/data quality; Ardent focuses on benchmarks and transformation maturity

Technology Adoption

Unified payments, touchless automation, modular platforms, phased approach

Comprehensive e-Payables, straight-through processing, payment networks, supplier enablement

Automation and integration drive efficiency and quality

SSON highlights touchless invoice challenges with non-PO invoices; Ardent quantifies automation maturity

AI & Analytics

Machine learning and AI for fraud, query handling, translation

AI for automation, forecasting, cost reduction; new metrics CAIT/SPOR

AI as future driver, but adoption is early

Ardent provides deeper metrics and analytics frameworks

Supplier Enablement

Centralized data, portals, feedback loops, high e-invoice adoption

Identifies supplier enablement as Achilles heel, calls for greater digital onboarding

Supplier participation key to transformation

SSON offers best practices; Ardent quantifies enablement gaps and solutions

Compliance & Risk

Proactive, embedded compliance for global mandates; layered fraud strategy

Compliance aligns with e-Invoicing, spend analytics; fraud prevention partnered with audit/IT

Compliance is central, fraud risk is rising

SSON more granular on regulation frameworks, e-invoicing challenges

 

North Carolina procurement and supply chain study

The latest NCSU study finds procurement and supply chain leaders are finally converging on shared strategic goals, but old operational silos haven’t vanished yet. Resilience, quality compliance, and sustainability now overshadow traditional cost and delivery metrics, reflecting the need to thrive amid ongoing disruption. Despite strategic alignment, execution gaps persist and can cost businesses dearly through slow decisions, increased risks, and missed opportunities for supply chain performance.

The report states that orchestration—coordinating people, processes, and tech has emerged as the practical fix for these gaps. The study shows workflow efficiency and cost savings are the top metrics organizations use to measure orchestration’s ROI. However adoption faces challenges: data quality, security concerns, and skills gaps stand out as the biggest of them.

The report states that leaders should prioritize cross-functional collaboration on risk and financial outcomes, invest in orchestration technology, pilot AI in key areas, and balance technical solutions with human readiness.

World Commerce and Contracting  - Contract Management

This report “Contract Management: An Overlooked Driver of Business Agility and Financial Performance” spotlights a hidden source of value erosion for organizations: dysfunctional contract management practices. The research reveals that businesses lose an average of 9% annual value due to poor contracting, with top-performing organizations limiting losses to 3%, while the worst experience up to 15% erosion. Procurement leaders are urged to examine how fragmented, slow, and rigid contracts undermine agility and financial outcomes.

The report points out recurring structural issues: siloed processes across Legal, Procurement, Finance, inconsistent skills among contract practitioners, and severe data fragmentation—contract data is scattered over an average of 24 separate systems. 83% of executives state contracts are too rigid to adapt during market shifts, directly impacting resilience and speed.

Effective contract management enables faster responses to disruption, operational alignment, and better exploitation of technologies like AI. The report’s roadmap to maturity encourages organizations to unlock competitive advantage and financial performance by treating contracting as a strategic enabler rather than a bureaucratic hurdle

Insights from CPO’s

Ahead of DPW in October this year, DPW released an e-book from DPW Amsterdam 2024 which has five leading Chief Procurement Officers to share actionable strategies shaping the next era of procurement.

Iris van den Harst (Equans Netherlands) urged starting small—focusing sustainability efforts with top-impact suppliers and industry alignment to standardize requests, which builds rapid credibility and measurable change. Shashi Mandapaty (Johnson & Johnson) frames procurement’s evolution as indispensable to corporate growth, advocating for supplier innovation, data stewardship, and an unyielding “no trade-off” mindset to create universal value across customers, employees, suppliers, and communities.

Modernizing procurement’s operation is another recurring theme. Sopan Shah (IHG Hotels & Resorts) recommends aligning tech with business strategy, leveraging new digital tools, and fostering cultures that allow experimentation and intelligent risk-taking. Klaus Staubitzer (Siemens) shows how embedding resilience across multi-tier supply chains and scaling pilots with clear KPIs turns procurement into a value-driving partner, while ensuring that AI initiatives genuinely support human expertise.

Fannie Boulanger (Airbnb) flips compliance-led procurement on its head, showing how culture-first leadership, speedy category strategy, and branding of procurement as a service transform stakeholder buy-in, especially during hypergrowth.

For procurement leaders, these lessons mean building innovation-centric teams, investing strategically in data and tech that empower—not replace—human judgment, and making procurement a central force for sustainable business impact

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!

Dear SKAE,

I see that we are implementing 4X9. As per below please see if the steps as per set up guide.

https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/SolS/EARL_SolS-013/2508/SolP/4X9?region=DE

This app calls the Document Information Extraction service to extract data from purchase order files. Currently, the app supports purchase orders in English or German (see Supported Languages (Base Edition)). You do not need to have an enterprise account on SAP Business Technology Platform (which requires a separate license) to use the service.

3. On the Deployments tab, activate the default deployment for all.

SD-SLS-IMP-DOX.

entry.title: Re: Table TOBJ list of authorization EHP8
entry.content: Hello @manthana99c17, SU25 is the way how to apply changes done by patch, SAP Note, upgrade, into your roles. In case of too much changes I guess it could be splitted directly using Step 2a - at first only for standard SAP space, including all steps as usually. Then it could be runned again, only for customer applications in customer space, all steps as above. Sometimes upgrade, SAP Note, patching brings no changes in authorization, sometimes yes. You can run SU25 every day but it will display only changes in authorizations in impact of installations on application level. No installation, no change 😁 Regarding auto update from SAP system, you mean regular maintenance proceeded on SAP system in SAP Cloud? As we are currently running S/4 conversion and moving our SAPs into SAP RISE Cloud, a final procedure how to deal with is not established yet. But thanks to your question, the first check using table/s USOBX* to see if anything has changed sounds like a good idea. If you will not run SU25, no changes would be applied into roles. It means if EHP8 would bring new auth object/s, new default values, or removal of any auth object/s, etc., for your roles this change will exist only after SU25. Of course, you can check if is needed, if any change has been caused, it's on you. But if changes with an impact to authorization happen, until SU25 finished, they can cause strange auth error/s. BR, Olga

entry.title: Re: set the condition rate using the attributes sent from...
entry.content: When using the CRM_COND_COM BADI to modify condition values in CRMD_ORDER, the BADI is designed to execute on save, not on a simple 'Enter' key press. The IPC (Internet Pricing and Configurator) executes more frequently, including on 'Enter.' The issue you're facing is a timing and data synchronization problem. Your BADI logic runs on save, updating a value, but the IPC re-calculates before this change is fully processed and communicated back to it. Consequently, the IPC's pricingCondition object doesn't have the updated value from your BADI when it performs its calculation, leading to the condition rate not changing. To correctly change the condition rate, the modification must be handled within the IPC userexit itself, using the data passed to it, or by ensuring the data is available to the IPC before its calculation step. The pricingCondition.setConditionRate() method is the correct way to change the value within the IPC, but it must be provided with the correct, updated data at the time of execution.

entry.title: Re: e-Doc Submission Error from SD Module Due to Missing...
entry.content: Check the Configuration in Table EDOCOMPANYACTIV Go to transaction SE16N or SM30 and open the table EDOCOMPANYACTIV. Verify the document types configured for your company code and country (Turkey). Ensure that SD_INVOICE is listed and active for Turkey. Update the Source Document Type In your SD billing process or e-Document configuration, replace SD_INVNOAC with SD_INVOICE. This change ensures compatibility with the Turkish Revenue Administration (GIB) integration. Adjust the e-Document Cockpit Settings Go to EDOC_COCKPIT and check the document type mappings. Make sure that the correct document type (SD_INVOICE) is used for Turkey. Test the Flow Again After updating the document type, reprocess the export document. Ensure the discharge date and other mandatory fields are populated before sending.
